body: Adding this to the milestone since I expect many people to run into this while migrating. Yes, the migration guide says that this is no longer needed, but I don't read the entire migration guide. I only check for the things that cause warnings or errors, and in this case, that didn't help.

Maybe this helps? I can think of some possible solutions:

## Restructure the ```struct State<S: States>(pub(crate) S)``` Resource as
```rust
struct State<S: States> {
   pub(crate) state: S,
   scoped_entities_initiated: bool,
}
```
and we add the following check to the ```enable_state_scoped_entities``` method in the ``impl AppExtStates for SubApp`` block 
```rust
if let Some(state) = self.world().get_resource::<State<S>>()
    && state.scoped_entities_initiated
{
    warn!("some warning");
    return self; // don't reinitiate state scoped entities
};
```
### Reservations
This should work, but each use case of ```State<S>``` would need to be refactored since it is no longer a tuple struct. Since S is private, this should only effect engine code. It also introduces a field to ```State<S>``` whose purpose is somewhat esoteric. 

## Handle the Errors
Entities are actually despawned in ```despawn_entities_on_exit_state<S: States>``` and ```despawn_entities_on_enter_state<S: States>```. We currently use ```commands.entity(entity).despawn();``` but we could change this to ```queue_handled``` to handle the errors. This does not address the root problem though.

## Make a Plugin
We could refactor the ```enable_state_scoped_entities``` method as a ```Plugin```. Since we have already have ```fn is_unique(&self) -> bool``` in the ```Plugin``` trait, it is trivial to ensure we do not enable scoped entities multiple times. This also has the benefit of not requiring changes to the ```State<S>``` struct. The main downside here is I don't believe bevy currently has the convention of having very small plugins (Such a plugin could be hard to find, but since state scoped entities are automatically enabled now, this is likely less of an issue).

## Just remove the ```enable_state_scoped_entities``` method
This is done automatically now, so perhaps there is no need, given the complications it causes?

##
Hopefully there is something better than the propositions above?

> Just remove the enable_state_scoped_entities method

This was my plan! If you want to tackle this today, please feel free :)
Hi Alice, I will take care of this today.

issue.body:
# Objective

- address #20866
- The simplest solution to the issue above is likely to simply remove the opt-out option for state-scoped entities

## Solution

- Given the popularity and low overhead of state-scoped entities, and the added complexity of allowing them to be disabled, it makes sense for state-scoped functionality to always be added when installing a State using the ```AppExtStates``` trait.
- Since state-scope entities are always enabled, the ```enable_state_scoped_entities``` method from ```AppExtStates``` was removed. This should fix the linked issue above.
- ```const SCOPED_ENTITIES_ENABLED: bool``` is no longer used, and was thus removed from ```States```. This had the positive consequence of simplifying the State derive macros.

## Addendum

- Given #19354, this is the next logical step. 
- Additionally, this impl block is in computed_states.rs:
```rust
impl<S: ComputedStates> States for S {
    const DEPENDENCY_DEPTH: usize = S::SourceStates::SET_DEPENDENCY_DEPTH + 1;

    const SCOPED_ENTITIES_ENABLED: bool = true;
}
```
So users cannot disable state-scoped entities for some States already!


Also, this is likely a controversial PR, so feedback would be appreciated. Thank you.

# Objective

- Reverts https://github.com/bevyengine/bevy/pull/16180
- Fixes #20866

## Solution

- Just enable state scoped entities all the time. No need to keep API surface for disabling that tiiiiiny bit of overhead. If someone needs this, we can still trivially add it back.

## Testing

- `bevy run --example state_scope`
